channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Rush expected for Queen's Birthday travel
item.description: Tourism businesses are expecting a cash injection over Queen's Birthday weekend as domestic tourists look to reclaim New Zealand's hotspots.

item.title: Covid-19 live updates from NZ and around the world on 29 May
item.description: From midday today, people will be able to gather in groups of up to 100, as level-2 restrictions are eased. Follow the latest updates here.

item.title: Covid-19: Wage subsidy auditing figures only collected quarterly - MSD
item.description: Up-to-date data on breaches of the $10 billion wage subsidy scheme are not being provided, with Carmel Sepuloni's office saying it is "not something we're interested in".

item.title: Gunfire sounds in Mamaku: police investigate
item.description: Police have surrounded an address west of Rotorua after several reports of shots being fired.

item.title: Iwi consultation not sought for permanent Endeavour replicas in Gisborne
item.description: Gisborne district councillors have voted to permanently install two new replicas of Captain Cook's ship the Endeavour in the region without consulting iwi or the public.

item.title: Hawke's Bay $1m drought funding 'doesn't go very far' - Rural Advisory Group
item.description: $1 million will be divided between thousands of Hawke's Bay farmers struggling with one of the worst droughts in a century.

item.title: Councillor upset rates rise on way for Christchurch residents
item.description: Christchurch residents face another rates hike, despite the economic challenges posed by Covid-19.

item.title: Changing our lives in a post-Covid world
item.description: The Detail: New Zealand's Covid-19 pandemic isn't done and dusted quite yet. But what lessons have we learned from the past two months - and how can we apply them to the future?

item.title: Teacher calls for schools to teach race issues following student's blackface post
item.description: Education can change the underbelly of racism within New Zealand, a teacher who is calling on schools to prioritise teaching the history of oppressed people says.

item.title: German engineers 'unsung heroes' of sewage pipeline
item.description: Engineers from Germany who left their families in the midst of a global pandemic and flew halfway around the world to help fix some broken sewer pipes are being hailed as heroes.

item.title: Air force medic recounts emotional find in Kahurangi National Park
item.description: New Zealand Defence Force medic Jase Denharder has revealed what happened when he reached trampers Dion Reynolds and Jessica O'Connor.

item.title: Man rescued after crossing Cook Strait in dinghy
item.description: An 18-year-old man who made an overnight trip across Cook Strait in a motorised dinghy had to be rescued after becoming stuck off the Mana Coast.

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in NZ and around the world on 28 May
item.description: One more death was added to New Zealand's Covid-19 tally as the US passed 100,000; the scale of job losses was revealed; however, no new cases for the sixth day in a row.

item.title: Cyclist dies after fatal collision
item.description: A cyclist has died after colliding with a truck in the Tauranga suburb of Mt Maunganui.

item.title: Sewage pipe burst in central Wellington, road closed
item.description: A burst sewage pipe has resulted in the closure of Victoria St in central Wellington.

item.title: No parole for convicted murderer Phillip John Smith
item.description: Convicted murderer, child sex offender and prison escapee Phillip John Smith has been denied parole after a New Zealand Parole Board hearing.

item.title: Govt announces multi-million dollar funding boost to help arts sector recover post-Covid
item.description: The government has announced a funding boost to help thousands of artists and creatives recover from the impact of Covid-19.

item.title: Most want to continue working from home... at least sometimes
item.description: A new study of people working from home during lockdown shows nearly all would like to continue doing so, at least some of the time.
